body: Try this flag `--no-gzip-encoding` not sure it will work, but fixing the above was its original purpose.

Thanks for the suggestion.  It didn't work for me.  Updated log below:

    2018/10/16 10:08:59 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.44-001-g67703a73-beta" starting with parameters ["./rclone" "-vv" "--no-gzip-encoding" "copy" "kevinish:9718a7ca-c0d4-41ac-a0dc-46922b9d541d/file.txt.gz" "file.txt.gz"]
    2018/10/16 10:08:59 DEBUG : Using config file from "/home/kevin/.config/rclone/rclone.conf"
    2018/10/16 10:09:00 DEBUG : file.txt.gz: Couldn't find file - need to transfer
    2018/10/16 10:09:00 ERROR : file.txt.gz: corrupted on transfer: sizes differ 47 vs 17
    2018/10/16 10:09:00 INFO  : file.txt.gz: Removing failed copy
    2018/10/16 10:09:00 ERROR : Attempt 1/3 failed with 1 errors and: corrupted on transfer: sizes differ 47 vs 17
    2018/10/16 10:09:00 DEBUG : file.txt.gz: Couldn't find file - need to transfer
    2018/10/16 10:09:00 ERROR : file.txt.gz: corrupted on transfer: sizes differ 47 vs 17
    2018/10/16 10:09:00 INFO  : file.txt.gz: Removing failed copy
    2018/10/16 10:09:00 ERROR : Attempt 2/3 failed with 1 errors and: corrupted on transfer: sizes differ 47 vs 17
    2018/10/16 10:09:00 DEBUG : file.txt.gz: Couldn't find file - need to transfer
    2018/10/16 10:09:00 ERROR : file.txt.gz: corrupted on transfer: sizes differ 47 vs 17
    2018/10/16 10:09:00 INFO  : file.txt.gz: Removing failed copy
    2018/10/16 10:09:00 ERROR : Attempt 3/3 failed with 1 errors and: corrupted on transfer: sizes differ 47 vs 17
    2018/10/16 10:09:00 Failed to copy: corrupted on transfer: sizes differ 47 vs 17

For reference, I think that flag would be counter-productive since the downloaded content needs to be gzipped so the MD5 and size can be verified.

Here it is obvious that the file has been decompressed

```
2018/10/16 18:55:11 DEBUG : <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<
2018/10/16 18:55:11 DEBUG : file2.txt.gz: Couldn't find file - need to transfer
2018/10/16 18:55:11 DEBUG : >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>
2018/10/16 18:55:11 DEBUG : HTTP REQUEST (req 0xc0004e8200)
2018/10/16 18:55:11 DEBUG : GET /download/storage/v1/b/rclone-test1/o/file2.txt.gz?generation=1539712477065527&alt=media HTTP/1.1
Host: www.googleapis.com
User-Agent: rclone/v1.44-DEV
Authorization: XXXX
Accept-Encoding: gzip

2018/10/16 18:55:11 DEBUG : >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>
2018/10/16 18:55:12 DEBUG : <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<
2018/10/16 18:55:12 DEBUG : HTTP RESPONSE (req 0xc0004e8200)
2018/10/16 18:55:12 DEBUG : HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Transfer-Encoding: chunked
Alt-Svc: quic=":443"; ma=2592000; v="44,43,39,35"
Cache-Control: no-cache, no-store, max-age=0, must-revalidate
Content-Disposition: attachment
Content-Language: en
Content-Type: text/plain
Date: Tue, 16 Oct 2018 17:55:11 GMT
Etag: CLfigfrDi94CEAE=
Expires: Mon, 01 Jan 1990 00:00:00 GMT
Pragma: no-cache
Server: UploadServer
Vary: Origin
Vary: X-Origin
X-Goog-Generation: 1539712477065527
X-Goog-Hash: crc32c=Aa5TQQ==,md5=551nL1Dz9AYIgwOywlL6iQ==
X-Goog-Metageneration: 1
X-Goog-Storage-Class: STANDARD
X-Guploader-Uploadid: AEnB2Uqsv4GHCnD6G9bokmvuP4OgReLq9Sz-lBSAoKNDMM7Tobxo_QgQlj_J8MkCpIwdlvt7wxBIhEtPBFIpkqEh4JQZyGQYxw

11
Example content.

0

2018/10/16 18:55:12 DEBUG : <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<
2018/10/16 18:55:12 ERROR : file2.txt.gz.download: corrupted on transfer: sizes differ 47 vs 17
```

When I compress the file with gzip first and upload it, it download fine with rclone.

I think the difference is in the Content-Types

```
$ rclone lsf --format mp gcs:rclone-test1
application/gzip;file.txt.gz  # uploaded with rclone
text/plain;file2.txt.gz # uploaded with gsutil -X
```

So it appears that the rclone auto decompressed the file (confusingly from 47 to 17 bytes), but as you said the md5sum of the file is for the compressed data, not the uncompressed.

Here is the help from gsutil which is enlightening

```
  -z <ext,...>   Applies gzip content-encoding to file uploads with the given
                 extensions. This is useful when uploading files with
                 compressible content (such as .js, .css, or .html files)
                 because it saves network bandwidth and space in Google Cloud
                 Storage, which in turn reduces storage costs.

                 When you specify the -z option, the data from your files is
                 compressed before it is uploaded, but your actual files are
                 left uncompressed on the local disk. The uploaded objects
                 retain the Content-Type and name of the original files but are
                 given a Content-Encoding header with the value "gzip" to
                 indicate that the object data stored are compressed on the
                 Google Cloud Storage servers.

                 For example, the following command:

                   gsutil cp -z html -a public-read cattypes.html gs://mycats

                 will do all of the following:

                 - Upload as the object gs://mycats/cattypes.html (cp command)
                 - Set the Content-Type to text/html (based on file extension)
                 - Compress the data in the file cattypes.html (-z option)
                 - Set the Content-Encoding to gzip (-z option)
                 - Set the ACL to public-read (-a option)
                 - If a user tries to view cattypes.html in a browser, the
                   browser will know to uncompress the data based on the
                   Content-Encoding header, and to render it as HTML based on
                   the Content-Type header.

                 Note that if you download an object with Content-Encoding:gzip
                 gsutil will decompress the content before writing the local
                 file.
```

So I think `--no-gzip-encoding` should be doing the right thing... Unfortunately it doesn't seem to be working as I can see rclone is still outputing `Accept-Encoding: gzip` - perhaps the SDK is overriding that.

However `--no-gzip-encoding` would download the file compressed which probably isn't what the user expects.

What would you expect rclone to do? Decompress the file?

> What would you expect rclone to do? Decompress the file?

My original goal was to transfer files from Google Cloud Storage to Azure Storage, so ideally it would transfer the compressed content exactly and preserve the Content-Encoding and MD5 metadata in the destination.

When copying a file from GCS to the local filesystem (or any where Content-Encoding is not declared), I think it makes the most sense to save the compressed content, both for performance reasons and so the MD5 can be verified (and preserved end-to-end in multi-step copies).  However, I could see a case for automatic decompression upon saving since `Content-Encoding` is often transparent to users (such as the use case described in the `gsutil` help you quoted).

Having a flag for user-selectable behavior might not be a bad idea.  I'm not sure which is the more reasonable default.  Perhaps the "automatic" default could choose based on the presence of a `.gz` extension?

I found a great article explaining this on gcs: https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/transcoding

So what I need to do is add the "Accept-Encoding: gzip" header which will have two effects
- gcs serves the file compressed
- the go transport won't automatically decompress it

I only add that for files with Content-Encoding: gzip which means I think it is safe to leave on permanently.

It seems likely that s3 has the same problem, but I haven't found their docs page yet!

I've made a beta with that in  here:

https://beta.rclone.org/branch/v1.44-003-g748b2fed-fix-2658-gcs-gzip-beta/ (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

That sounds great!  I tested the beta and it successfully downloaded the compressed file and preserved the MD5.  Excellent!  Thank you!

However, I noticed that it doesn't preserve the Content-Encoding (or custom metadata) when copying from GCS to Azure.  Should I open a separate issue for that, or would you like to discuss in this one?  In either case, I will write up more details and a test case.

Thanks again!

> That sounds great! I tested the beta and it successfully downloaded the compressed file and preserved the MD5. Excellent! Thank you!

:-)
 
> However, I noticed that it doesn't preserve the Content-Encoding (or custom metadata) when copying from GCS to Azure. Should I open a separate issue for that, or would you like to discuss in this one? 

There are two sorts of metadata, general purpose key, value storage and what I'll call HTTP metadata
- Access control metadata
- Cache-Control
- Content-Disposition
- Content-Encoding
- Content-Language
- Content-Type

Rclone deals with `Content-Type` already but it doesn't deal with the other kinds of metadata.

There is an issue already about custom metadata #111.  That is quite an old issue but I think it would be much easier to implement now-a-days.  You'll see various other issues linked from there.

It would be nice if rclone could copy metadata from cloud to cloud, and also set it on upload.  This would be a reasonably big project though!

The way it would work is that I'd give each Object an optional interface `ReadMetadata` and that would be supplied.  On upload this would be read and set on the object.

> In either case, I will write up more details and a test case.

That would be useful - can you put it in #111.  I'll move that issue up into the run Q since I think its time has come :-)

I think the only thing I'm not sure about is how to represent the http metadata and the non http metadata in a cross cloud sort of way.  Perhaps ReadMetadata should return two dictionaries or one dictionary and one `http.Header`

Thinking aloud this could also subsume the `Content-Type` mechanism.

Docs
- gcs: https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/metadata
- azureblob: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/storageservices/get-blob-properties
- s3: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/UsingMetadata.html

This could also (with a flag) be implemented as attributes on local files.
That sounds great.  Thanks for the detailed explanation!

issue.title: Feature request: Copy custom metadata on objects

milestone.title: Help Wanted
milestone.description:
Enhancements which might be useful, but currently aren't planned.

Any help doing these much appreciated.

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
For object storage systems that support custom (user defined) metadata types, include a flag (`-meta`?) that will also copy custom metadata from source to destination. For example, if copying/migrating data from Amazon S3 to Swift, or from Swift to Swift, it would be very handy to be able to maintain any custom metadata set on the objects.

* Please don't comment if you have no relevant information to add. It's just extra noise for everyone subscribed to this issue.
* Subscribe to receive notifications on status change and new comments.

issue.title: the suggestions to implement of a "-z <file extensions>" and a "-Z" flags

milestone.title: Soon
milestone.description: Issues which are a good idea but haven't been assigned a specific release yet.

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### What is your current rclone version (output from `rclone version`)?
rclone v1.47.0
- os/arch: linux/amd64
- go version: go1.12.4

#### What problem are you are trying to solve?
I trying to compress all files or some files filtered by their extensions during uploading it to gcs, s3, and other providers buckets which allow us to set the metadata `'Content-Encoding: gzip'` for compressed files

#### How do you think rclone should be changed to solve that?
it would be great to implement a `-z <file extensions>` and `-Z` flags to solve managing of compressed files and allowing to set `'Content-Encoding: gzip'` for such uploaded files on remote

that implemented in gsutil as flags `-Z` and `-z` and well documented [here](https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/gsutil/commands/cp#options).

related info: 
- [2658](https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/2658) 
- [111#issuecomment-493052098](https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/111#issuecomment-493052098)
